item.title: R and Python
item.description: Python and R generic Here’s just some code I took from Worksheet 21: library(reticulate) py_config() ## python: /stor/home/mgb2576/.local/share/r-miniconda/envs/r-reticulate/bin/python ## libpython: /stor/home/mgb2576/.local/share/r-miniconda/envs/r-reticulate/lib/libpython3.6m.so ## pythonhome: /stor/home/mgb2576/.local/share/r-miniconda/envs/r-reticulate:/stor/home/mgb2576/.local/share/r-miniconda/envs/r-reticulate ## version: 3.6.13 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Feb 19 2021, 05:36:01) [GCC 9.3.0] ## numpy: /stor/home/mgb2576/.local/share/r-miniconda/envs/r-reticulate/lib/python3.6/site-packages/numpy ## numpy_version: 1.19.5 py_install("pandas") py_install("matplotlib") matplotlib <- import("matplotlib") matplotlib$use("Agg", force = TRUE) import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import pandas x=np.random.normal(0,1,50) y=np.random.normal(0,1,50) plt.scatter(x,y) library(ggplot2) ggplot()+geom_point(aes(py$x,py$y)) Here’s an actual conversation between Python and R I devised (I’m not very good with graphs):
